title: Tools
text: This is an overview of tools we use. Details on how we use them are laid out in other pages in the handbook.

title: Tools
text:
Handbook
You’re reading the handbook in Notion. We use Notion to create internal docs that show how R for the Rest of Us runs.

title: Tools
text:
Communication
Email happens through Gmail. We have access to the full Google Suite tools, but only use Docs, Sheets, etc periodically.
Twist is where we communicate internally.

title: Tools
text:
Task/Project Management
We use Todoist to lay out tasks to be done on projects. Generally speaking, we only lay out major milestones on Todoist projects (e.g. finish all data viz on X project on July 23). Communication about specific tasks should happen in the comments section of those tasks.
Code-based projects have major milestones laid out in Todoist, but then use GitHub to discuss individual issues.

title: Tools
text:
Time Tracking
Time tracking happens in Toggl.

title: Tools
text:
Scheduling
We use SavvyCal to schedule meetings with clients.

title: Tools
text:
Financial
We use QuickBooks for accounting and invoicing.
Payroll happens through Gusto.

title: Tools
text:
Proposal and Contracts
Proposals and contracts are written and sent with PandaDoc.

title: Tools
text:
Design
We use Figma to make all design assets.

title: Tools
text:
Passwords
We manage passwords with 1Password.

title: Tools
text:
Website
The website runs on WordPress and is hosted by Kinsta. There are various paid plugins that help do specific things on the website. See Website.
Website analytics are provided by Fathom.

title: Tools
text:
Video Creation
When providing quick feedback videos, we use CloudApp.
To record videos for courses, we use either Screenflow, OBS Studio, Streamlabs (depending on instructor operating system + preferences).
Video editing happens in Screenflow.
Captions for videos are made using muse.ai.

title: Tools
text:
Video Hosting
Course videos, teaching videos, etc are hosted on muse.ai and embedded on the website.
There is an R for the Rest of Us YouTube channel that I’ve only periodically used.

title: Tools
text:
Social Media
We use two tools to schedule social media content:

Buffer is where we set up a queue of regular R content created by others to go out on Twitter.
If we need to schedule Twitter threads, we use Typefully.

title: Tools
text:
Automation
We use Zapier to automate various processes (e.g. when a user completes a course, Zapier sends that data to ConvertKit).

title: Course Manual
text:
Legal and Financial
Here are the legal and financial terms that I typically use when working with course instructors. I’m flexible and happy to work with you to come up with a solution that meets both of our needs.

Compensation
I pay an advance to the course creator of $500, half on signing the contract to work together, and the other half when all videos for the course are recorded and uploaded to Google Drive.
Revenue for the courses is split 60/40 (60% for R for the Rest of Us, 40% for the course creator). I pay any royalties owed to the course creator on a quarterly basis.


Ownership
All videos are owned by R for the Rest of Us.
All non-video materials will be made freely available on the R for the Rest of Us organization GitHub using a CC-BY-SA-4.0 License.


Exclusivity
The instructor agrees not to create a course that covers the same topic on another online platform for at least 12 months from the release of this course.


Agreement Expiration
These terms remain in effect for one year after the course is released. After that, David and the instructor will discuss any possible changes to the terms.

title: Course Manual
text:
Curriculum Development
You’ll develop your curriculum as a combination of slides, exercises, and examples. Here’s how I’ve used the three, but please note that this is just my approach. I want you to think about what’s going to work best for your materials.
I start out each section of my course with slides. In my courses, a section is RMarkdown or data wrangling and analysis or data visualization. I have a slide with the section title that I display as I talk through an overview of that section.
Each lesson within a section should be short and focus on a single topic. As you’re making your materials, if you think that a video demonstrating the concept will go beyond 5 minutes or so, consider breaking it into multiple lessons.
I typically start a lesson with slides. I’ll start with a slide that lays out the concept. I’ll often have code on this slide.
 I’ll usually then flip over to RStudio to show myself typing out the code to demonstrate this concept in an exercises file.
You can see an example of a whole lesson, complete with all parts here.

Lesson Content
I usually use a Google Sheet to help collaborate with the instructor on course materials. Here’s a sample of what the Google Sheet includes. The Google Sheet has places for thinking about lesson content, data, exercises, solutions, and learn more resources.

title: Course Manual
text:
RStudio Setup

Defaults
Please use default fonts while you are teaching. Pretty as they are, please don’t use fonts like Fira Code, as the differences in how they render the assignment operator, for example, can be confusing for newbies.

title: Course Manual
text:
Code Style
Please follow the tidyverse style guide as closely as possible. The most important thing is to have code that is easy to read for new learners. You’re welcome to use the styler package to format your code.

title: Course Manual
text:
Recording Videos
I record using Screenflow. If you’re on a Mac, you’ll get a license for it. If not, we’ll discuss options.

Recording Procedures
I’m generally not that fussy about making sure everything is super high quality, but please use an external camera and external mic to record. Please put your mic as close to you as possible, but make sure it doesn’t show up on camera. If you are interested in learning some tips about high-quality screencasting, this guide from Egghead is helpful.
My general experience is that it’s easier to record videos by just hitting record and going through your lesson as many times as you need to. I often make mistakes along the way, but that’s ok because we can edit them out after the fact. Just go back to right before you messed up and start again! You can, of course, record so you get a single high-quality take, but I find that hard to do and way too much pressure.


Sharing Videos with David
Please share the raw videos you record in the Google Drive folder that David sets up for you. Make sure they are labeled so I know what each video is.

title: Course Manual
text:
Video Editing
David will edit all of your videos.

title: Website
text: R for the Rest of Us runs on a WordPress website hosted by Kinsta.

title: Website
text:
Theme
The site uses the BuddyBoss theme. Some of the most important pages (e.g. Home, About, Consulting) are generated with custom templates that use Tailwind CSS. These are edited locally, the templates are pushed to this GitHub repo, and then the WP Pusher plugin adds them to the website.

title: Website
text:
Custom Post Types
I’ve created several custom post types using the Pods plugin:

Clients hosts pages with content for specific clients
Presentations
Resources hosts resources for the resources page
Success Stories hosts pages that highlight successful projects we’ve worked on
Thanks hosts various pages that say thanks to people (used mostly for when people click things in ConvertKit)

title: Website
text:
Plugins
The website uses many plugins. Here are some of the most important and less obvious ones.
AffiliateWP enables us to have affiliates who are paid for referring customers (not currently using this)
BuddyBoss Platform + BuddyBoss Platform Pro hosts groups and forums for cohort-based courses
ConvertKit allows me to do things like apply a tag to a customer whenever they purchase a course
FacetWP is what I use to create a searchable, filterable resources page
LearnDash is probably the most important plugin. It is what we use to manage all courses. BuddyBoss integrates with it, making the course pages even more attractive. The one thing to note with LearnDash is that we use WooCommerce for signup and just use LearnDash itself for the course stuff.
Loco Translate allows us to use different terms for things (e.g. Meetings instead of Zoom in BuddyBoss)
NinjaForms is what we use for all forms
Pods creates custom post types
SEOPress + SEOPress Pro is used for all SEO stuff
WooCommerce is how we handle all ecommerce on the site. We also use add-on Woo plugins:

WooCommerce Price Based on Country allows us to set lower prices for those in lower GDP countries
WooCommerce Product Vendors allows us to track commissions for course instructors
WooCommerce Smart Coupons allows us to set up coupons for gift certificates
WooCommerce Stripe Gateway allows us to use Stripe to process credit cards (we also reluctantly use PayPal)
WooCommerce Zapier allows us to create coupons for users from using Zapier when they are in their pitch window (see Email Marketing)

WP Pusher syncs our child theme from this GitHub repo to the website

title: Welcome
text: Welcome! You are reading an in-progress version of the R for the Rest of Us handbook.

title: Welcome
text:
Mission
The goal of R for the Rest of Us is to help people use R to do good in the world.

title: Welcome
text:
Our Work
The business has two main arms: education and consulting.

Education
On the education side, we offer:

Self-paced and cohort-based courses
In-person public workshops
Custom training for organizations



Consulting
On the consulting side, we do a range of projects. Almost all of them involve some combination of:

Data visualization
Using R to improve workflows
Automating reporting (especially with parameterized reporting)

title: Welcome
text:
Roadmap
As a business that does both education and consulting work, the R for the Rest of Us roadmap is guided by internal and external factors. We do our best to be thoughtful about future directions we think are useful based on customer feedback while also leaving space to adjust based on new information.

title: Welcome
section: A Business with a Social Conscience
text:
A Business with a Social Conscience
R for the Rest of Us is not just a money-making enterprise. I also want it to be a business with a social conscience. We put this into practice by:

Highlighting important issues in the work we do (e.g. the types of projects we work on)
Making it possible for people of various means to learn R (through parity purchasing power and scholarships)
Donating a portion of revenue to organizations working for social justice

title: Welcome
text:
People
R for the Rest of Us is headed by David Keyes. I’ve outlined my role in David’s Responsibilities.
Current consultants include Charlie Hadley, Thomas Vroylandt, and Cara Thompson. Other consultants are brought in for individual projects.

title: Welcome
text:
Clients
Here is a list of clients we have worked with and a sample of the projects we’ve worked on with them.
API Council: San Francisco-based non-profit that advocates for the Asian Pacific Islander community. We built a food resources map for them in 2021.
Aspect Evaluation: Very small (one-person, I believe) evaluation firm in Seattle. We made some visualizations for them in 2020.
CTData: Connecticut-based non-profit. We worked with them and their client the Partnership for Strong Communities to make housing reports in 2020.
Evaluation by Design: Very small (one-person, I believe) evaluation firm in the Bay Area. We helped them to develop strategy and reporting on their 21st century skills training program.
Ford Family Foundation: The client we’ve worked with the longest (since ~2017). We’ve done several data viz projects for them. The most notable is Oregon by the Numbers, but we’ve also done multiple internal projects.
ISTE/EdSurge: A non-profit education news site. We did a couple data visualizations for them focused on COVID and school reopening in 2020.
Michigan Fitness Foundation: Non-profit focused on health. We have been doing custom training with them (mostly in the form of regular check-in calls) since 2020.
OMNI Institute: Colorado-based evaluation firm. We trained their staff on R in 2019. Since then, we’ve done some additional training for them as well as some smaller consulting projects around survey reporting.
ORS Impact: Seattle-based evaluation firm. We’re currently helping them with a set of reports on 2020 Census outreach efforts.
Pacific Research and Evaluation: A Portland-based evaluation firm, we trained them in R in 2019. Since then, we’ve done a few small consulting projects for them, mostly around making maps.
Prosper Portland: Small business development agency for the city of Portland. We did a training with their data team in 2019. We’ve also done a series of smaller consulting projects with them since then.
Public Profit: Oakland-based evaluation firm. We trained their team in 2018.
Reading Partners: National non-profit that promotes literacy. We trained their team in 2019. We also developed an internal dashboard for them.
TORV LLC: Colorado-based consulting firm that works with golf courses and sports fields. We’re helping them to automate reporting.
The Mark: Southern California-based evaluation firm. They took some of our courses as a group in 2020 and had us develop some docs for them.

text:
The best description of branding that I’ve read is from Gumroad:
When I think about who typical customers are for education products, here’s the persona I have in mind:
With this persona in mind, I’ve intentionally tried to make the R for the Rest of Us personality:
All of the marketing I do takes a laid-back, conversational approach. I start all emails, for example, with the phrase “Hi friend”. Any time someone asks a question, I reassure them it’s a good question (people are afraid to ask “dumb” questions when it comes to R). These are a couple ways I try to implement the brand.

title: Branding
text:
Logo, colors, typography
When most people think of branding, this is what they’re asking about. You can find the various logos, colors, and typography that I use on Canva.

title: Social Media
text:
Social media is the main marketing strategy to help people become aware of R for the Rest of Us. The main platform we use is Twitter, as that’s where most R users are. We also market through LinkedIn.
All social media is designed not so much to sell directly (though we do a bit of this), but to get people on the R for the Rest of Us email list (see Email Marketing). Once they are on that list, we attempt to educate them and convince them to buy products form us.

title: Social Media
text:
Twitter
Active R users are on Twitter. We try to reach them not so much to sell to them directly (though this does sometimes happen), but more to have them connect people looking to learn R (who currently users are likely to know) with R for the Rest of Us.

We find R content produced by others and tweet it out on weekdays at 6am using Buffer.
We share R for the Rest of Us content on Thursdays at 9am using MeetEdgar. We have a library full of content that we’ve created, each of which has multiple variations. MeetEdgar automatically picks out a random tweet from the RRU Content category and shares it every week.
We also regularly share promotional material (i.e. links directly to a course) using Buffer, MeetEdgar, or Typefully (if we want to schedule a thread). We don’t currently have a schedule for this, but probably should.

title: Social Media
text:
LinkedIn
We don’t currently have a plan for using LinkedIn, but we should. Where Twitter is focused on for connecting with individuals, our LinkedIn strategy should be focused on getting management-type people to think about inquiring about our custom training and/or consulting offerings.

title: Project Management
text:
The overall way we manage projects is this:

Overall milestones live in Todoist
Code-related granular issues live in GitHub
Any general discussion about projects can go in GitHub discussions or in a thread on Twist

Starting out, think about the major milestones in a project. These should be put into Todoist. This allows David (or anyone, in fact) to see the major milestones and associated timing for a project.
From there, a GitHub repo (set to private unless the client is ok with it being public) should be created.

Use the README to lay out the overall project scope, deliverables, etc.
Use issues to manage code-related questions at a granular level.
If it’s helpful, feel free to use milestones (they would largely just mirror the Todoist tasks, though, so it’s not necessary).
You can also enable GitHub Discussions to discuss more general things.

We can also use Twist to communicate about projects. This is a good place for things we’d like to keep confidential (because we work more and more with clients directly in GitHub, that isn’t the best place for confidential discussions).

title: Project Management
text:
Client Communication
The most important thing we can do is communicate effectively and regularly. This means getting back to clients within 24 hours.
The type of communication we use with clients depends on the client.

If clients are comfortable working in GtiHub, feel free to add them to the appropriate repo.
If they don’t want to work in GitHub (most don’t), email is generally best.

I generally try to send clients updates by email about overall progress every 1-2 weeks to make sure they know what’s going on and see if they have any questions.

title: Finances
text:
R for the Rest of Us finances are managed using QuickBooks.
We do the following tasks in the first week of each month:
Categorize and approve all expenses in QuickBooks: If unclear on category, first look at previous months. If still unclear, ask David.
Send invoices to clients with QuickBooks: Time should be checked on Toggl reports and an invoice should be generated for each client. Some projects are billed hourly while others are billed at a flat rate (details are in the associated Todoist tasks).
Pay contractors with Gusto: All contractors will submit an invoice each month. They are then paid with Gusto.

title: Finances
text:
Quarterly Tasks
Each quarter we reconcile accounts in QuickBooks. This is done by getting statements from both Advantis Credit Union and Mercury and then entering balances here. This compares the balances in my bank accounts to those in QuickBooks to make sure everything matches up.
I also pay course instructors each quarter. You can go to the commission report on the website and see which commissions are unpaid. You can total these up for each instructor (they’re called a vendor on this part of the website) and then pay them through Gusto. Each instructor gets an advance so they only start receiving commissions when they earn more than the advance.

title: Finances
text:
Annual Tasks
We send out 1099s to all contractors by Gusto. I’ve set Gusto up to make sure this happens, but we should check to confirm this in mid-January.

title: Email Automations
text:
Email marketing is the main way that R for the Rest of Us brings in revenue.
All external marketing is designed to get people onto the R for the Rest of Us email list. Once they’re on the list, we send them regular emails that educate them about R, interspersing emails that attempt to sell them on our offerings.
The specifics of how our email marketing system works comes largely from Brennan Dunn’s Mastering ConvertKit course. The process gets fairly complicated, but at the highest level, here’s what it does:
Below are details about how email automations work. Note that sequences aren’t included because they are generally just called from Visual Automations below.

title: Email Automations
text:
Signup
Here are the signup journeys that users experience on the R for the Rest of Us email list.

Getting Started
If the user gets onto the list by signing up for Getting Started, they get the tag Purchased - Getting Started applied through the WooCommerce-ConvertKit integration.
They then go through the Getting Started - Signup - Automation. This does the following:

Assigns the tag Customer - Course/Workshop
Assigns the tag Customer
Assigns the tag Flag - Calculate Next offer (which sends them through the Function - Calculate Offer Funnel and Expertise Level - Automation)
Assigns the Flag - Remove from Shadow Newsletter tag, which does what it says
Puts them through the Getting Started - Signup - Sequence, which sends a set of emails about the course
When they complete the course or the Getting Started - Signup - Sequence, they get pulled to the end and go into the Fundamentals - Bridge - Automation

The Fundamentals - Bridge - Automation pitches people on Fundamentals. It happens in two ways depending on what the user has done so far on Getting Started.

If the user has the Completed - Getting Started tag, they go into the Fundamentals - Bridge - Hot. This goes straight to the pitch for Fundamentals.
If the user has not completed Getting Started, they go into the Fundamentals - Bridge - Cold. This sends them a few emails before pitching them on Fundamentals.

After they go through the bridge sequences, they go into the Fundamentals - Pitch - Automation.

The tag Flag - Pitch Window Open - Fundamentals gets applied. This triggers Zapier to create a personalized coupon on WooCommerce.
The user gets an email on Friday telling them their personal window is open to purchase Fundamentals.
The user goes through the Fundamentals - Pitch - Sequence, which sends an email every day the next week with info on purchasing Fundamentals.
The tag Completed - Onboarding is applied.
The tag Flag - Start Shadow Newsletter is applied. This triggers the Shadow Newsletter - Automation and adds them to the shadow newsletter.



Other Courses

If they sign up for a course, each Woo products assigns them the appropriate tag (e.g. Purchased - Fundamentals).
Then, they go through a visual automation for each course (e.g. Fundamentals - Signup - Automation)
Then, this automation rule assigns them the tag Flag - New Subscriber.



R in 3 Months

If they sign up for R in 3, WooCommerce assigns them the tag Purchased - R in 3 Months.
Then, they go through this visual automation, which sends them an email that welcomes them. All other communication about R in 3 Months happens directly via Gmail



Newsletter
If someone signs up for the newsletter using this form, the following happens:

The Flag - New Subscriber tag is added to them through this automation rule

The Flag - New Subscriber tag puts them into the Global - Welcome - Sequence using this automation rule

The Flag - New Subscriber tag being added puts them onto the New Subscriber - Automation
The New Subscriber - Automation moves them through the Function - Calculate Offer Funnel and Expertise Level - Automation
The New Subscriber - Automation moves them through the Function - Tag Custom Training/Consulting Clients - Automation

If they are a custom training/consulting client, they get the Completed - Onboarding and the Flag - Start Shadow Newsletter tags applied, which moves them onto the shadow newsletter
If they are not a custom training/consulting client, they are moved to the Getting Started - Pitch - Automation (if they haven’t signed up for it)




You can do that with R
Note: This one is basically archived. It was a lead magnet early on but isn’t really necessary anymore because most people sign up for Getting Started.

If user signs up for you can do that, it happens with this form.
Then, this automation rule assigns them the tag Flag - New Subscriber.

title: Email Automations
text:
Shadow Newsletter
Any time the tag Flag - Start Shadow Newsletter is added to a user, they go through the Shadow Newsletter - Automation. This does the following:

Removes the Flag - Start Shadow Newsletter tag (so it can be added again)
Checks if they’ve completed part 1 of the shadow newsletter. If not, puts them onto that sequence. If so, moves onto the next part.
Repeats the previous step through each part of the shadow newsletter.

After the user completes each part of the shadow newsletter, they get the tag Locked - Pitched added. This puts them onto Function - Move to Pitch - Automation.

title: Email Automations
text:
Pitching

Calculate Next Offer
When the user gets put onto Function - Move to Pitch - Automation:

The user goes through the Function - Calculate Offer Funnel and Expertise Level - Automation, which calculates their next offer
Based on the custom field next_offer, the user is put onto a PRODUCT - Pitch - Auomation for their next offer.



Self-Paced Course Pitch
All self-paced course pitches follow the same pattern as Fundamentals:

The user gets an email on Friday telling them their personal window is open to purchase Fundamentals.
The user goes through the Fundamentals - Pitch - Sequence, which sends an email every day the next week with info on purchasing Fundamentals.

title: Marketing Overview
text:
Don’t market, educate.

By educating, we show people what R is and what you can do with it. Once they appreciate these things, they’re more likely to want to learn R themselves or to hire us to help them do something with it.

title: Communication
text:
As a fully remote company, we try to communicate by writing as much as possible. Doing so has many benefits:

It forces us to clarify our thinking
It provides a record of decisions for those who may join things midstream
It allows people to work on their own time without feeling the need to join live calls etc

Internal communication happens, as much as possible, in Twist. There are currently two channels:

#admin for David and Nicole to discuss admin tasks
#general for everything else

Other places internal communication happens include:

GitHub for discussion of specific issues on code-based projects
Todoist comments for questions on specific tasks to be done

title: Communication
text:
External Communication
External communication with clients and others happens mostly through email.
